properties.name: Destination Address Name
properties.description: Name of the object to handle destination address. This will be populated automatically.

properties.name: observable_type
properties.description: Any type of the supported observables. You can check the list here: https://ciscosecurity.github.io/sxo-05-security-workflows/workflows/response/overview#valid-observable-types

properties.name: Destination Address Group Name
properties.description: Name of the group to contain destination address objects. Leave this value empty if you want to create a new Destination Address Group.

properties.name: observable_value
properties.description: Variable to receive the data from the ServiceNow triggering request.

properties.name: Access Token
properties.description: Access token for the FortiGate API. This can be generated by creating a new REST API Admin under System > Administrators

properties.name: Source Address Name
properties.description: Name of the object to handle destination address. This will be populated automatically.

properties.name: Name Prefix
properties.description: Name Prefix for names of the objects which will be created automatically.

properties.name: Service Name
properties.description: Name of the Service. This will be populated automatically.

properties.name: Source Address Group Name
properties.description: Name of the group to contain destination address objects. Leave this value empty if you want to create a new Source Address Group.

properties.name: Service Group Name
properties.description: The Name of the Service Group to be updated with the provided observable value. Leave this value empty if you want to create a new Service Group.

This workflow is triggered by creating the "Request Firewall Rule" task in ServiceNow. When triggered, it gets data (IP, port, protocol, e.t.) from the triggering request body and updates a firewall policy on a Fortinet - FortiGate firewall according to the received parameters.

Note: You may need to use a SecureX Orchestration Remote to communicate with FortiGate if it's on-premise. See: https://cs.co/SXO_remote

Target Group: Default TargetGroup

Targets: FortiGate_API, ServiceNow_API

Steps:
[] Validate input data
[] Create/reuse addresses and service to handle input data
[] Use provided groups corresponding to the objects
[] Update provided firewall policy 
[] Move policy on top of the policies list
[] Send summary message as a Work Note to ServiceNow Firewall Rule Task

More information about this API:  [placeholder]

properties.script:
import json
import sys

def read_possible_range_value(value):
    value = [part.strip() for part in value.split('-')]
    return '-'.join(value)

def read_protocol(protocol):
    assert protocol in ('tcp', 'udp')
    return protocol

def read_action(action):
    action_mapping = {'allow': 'accept', 'block': 'deny'}
    return action_mapping[action.lower()]
#
input_data = json.loads(sys.argv[1])
destination_address = None
destination_address_type = None
source_address = None
destination_service = None
protocol = None
action = None
sn_task_id = None
error = None
error_mapping = {
    KeyError: 'Input Data Error. Input JSON is not valid.',
    AttributeError: "Input Data Error. Destination port (port range) can't be empty.",
    AssertionError: "Input Data Error. The protocol has to be one of TCP or UDP."
}
try:
    sn_task_id = input_data["ServiceNow Task ID"]
    destination_address = read_possible_range_value(input_data["Destination Host IP"])
    source_address = read_possible_range_value(input_data["Source Host IP"])
    destination_service = read_possible_range_value(input_data["Destination Port"])
    protocol = read_protocol(input_data["Protocol"].lower())
    policy = input_data["Access Policy Name"]
    action = read_action(input_data["Access Action"])
except tuple(error_mapping) as exception:
    error = error_mapping[exception.__class__]
